thread.title: Alabama defensive front consistently disruptive in win over Texas A
thread.title_full: Alabama defensive front consistently disruptive in win over Texas A

author: Matt Zenitz | mzenitz@al.com
title: Alabama defensive front consistently disruptive in win over Texas A
text:
Comments 
Texas A&M quarterback Kyle Allen immediately grabbed his right shoulder after being brought to the ground. 
Facing a third-and-10 at Alabama's 29-yard line during the third quarter, Allen rolled right after being unable to spot an open receiver. 
As was the case much of the game, the Tide provided resistance. 
Inside linebacker Reggie Ragland took off in Allen's direction once Allen began to roll out, progressively closing and bearing down before sacking the quarterback from the side in a way that he fell hard on his right shoulder. 
Consistently disruptive against both the run and pass, Alabama finished its 41-23 win over Texas A&M with 12 tackles for a loss, six sacks and three additional quarterback hurries. 
The pressure was key in the Tide limiting the Aggies — which entered the game ranked 15 th nationally with an average of 39.2 points per game — to 316 yards and 16 offensive points. 
"I think that they pass the ball a lot," Alabama coach Nick Saban said. "They weren't able to run it. We created a lot of passing situations, which lets us play the kind of defense that lets players pin their ears back a little bit and us to make calls that enhance pressure. We're fortunate to have some pretty good guys who can execute it and do a good job in that regard." 
Affected by the pressure, Allen finished 20 of 40 with one touchdown and three interceptions. 
He also fumbled once on a hard sack from Alabama defensive lineman Jonathan Allen, who threw a Texas A&M guard out of the way to free himself for a clear run at Allen. 
Allen was sacked five times. 
Freshman quarterback Kyler Murray — who also saw time — was sacked once as well. 
Murray was 2 of 4 with no touchdowns and an interception. 
Tra Carson — the Aggies' 6-foot, 235-pound running back — ran for 110 yards in Texas A&M's previous game, a win over Mississippi State. 
The Tide held Carson to 46 yards on 13 carries, an average of 3.5 yards per attempt. 
Including sacks, the Aggies finished with 32 yards on 25 carries. 
Allen was one of the primary catalysts for Alabama's defense. He had five tackles, four stops for a loss, two sacks and the forced fumble. 
Nine different Tide players had at least a shared tackle for a loss. 
Allen, Ragland, safety Ronnie Harrison and outside linebackers Ryan Anderson and Tim Williams all had at least one sack. 
To put the numbers into perspective, Arizona State ranks first nationally in tackles for a loss per game with 9.86. 
Utah is first in sacks with 4.23 per game. 
"When it's second-and-5, it's hard to rush the passer," Saban said. "When it's second-and-10, it's a lot easier. When it's third-and-8, it's a lot easier. We created a lot of those situations in the game, and I think we were able to affect the quarterback because of it."
